user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskMatch_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TaskMatch_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_task_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_task_table, *token);

    if (pthread_equal(pthread_self(), impl->id) == 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskMatch_Impl:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_task_internal_record_t OS_impl_task_table[OS_MAX_TASKS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_t id;
} OS_impl_task_internal_record_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other code fragments in the function do not perform any assignment to the function parameter token nor do they cast away its const-qualifier or otherwise rebind the pointer itself. The calls to pthread_equal(pthread_self(), impl->id), the returns, and the use of impl do not modify the parameter token (they only read from the object table or compare thread IDs). The only places that could lead to modification of the parameter or the object it denotes are the function signature (how token is declared), the use of *token as the macro argument, and the macro definition which takes the address of the macro argument and passes it to OS_ObjectIndexFromToken — these need inspection to ensure no write or const-discarding modification occurs. No other fragments in the provided code require investigation for Rule 17.8.
